comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: According to this history of the Sterling, she was recommissioned on February 2, 1916. www.navsource.org/archives/09/02/0297.htm She was in the news on February 6, 1916: "JEWISH AID ON WARSHIP.; Collier Sterling to Carry Medicines to Sufferers from the War. The consignment of medicines that the Central Committee for the Relief of Jews Suffering Through the War is sending to Palestine is to be carried across the Atlantic by the naval collier Sterling. Albert Lucas, Chairman of the Central Committee, received word from Secretary of the Navy Daniels yesterday that space allotment for the goods had been made on the Sterling and that she would probably sail from New York about Feb. 15." select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40C14F83E5F1773...

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Note that the navsource.org site artolog points to reckons the picture was taken "at anchor in the Hudson River, 3 October 1911, near the New York Navy Yard during that year's Presidential Naval Review." See www.navsource.org/archives/09/02/09029701.jpg

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content: artolog and swanq: Thanks for the information on the Sterling. I would venture the date mis-match you noticed, swanq, could be the result of the Bain News Service making a copy photograph in 1916 of the 1911 image. We will add more of info to the record when updating. Thank you!
